intro: Carpodetus grandiflorus, commonly known as the large-flowered tamarack, is a species of flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Ericaceae family, which includes heathers and blueberries, and is characterized by its evergreen foliage and showy, bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, acidic soils and is often found in mountainous regions. Its botanical features include small, leathery leaves and clusters of white or pink flowers that bloom in the spring. It plays an important ecological role in its native habitat by providing nectar for pollinators and shelter for small wildlife.
